Sample_preparation: Samples was added to 6% pyrogallol solution (in ethanol). After vortex 2 min, N2_flushing and sonication of 60% KOH solution (in distilled water) was added for saponification reaction. Afterward, 20 mL of 2% NaCl solution (in distilled water) was added to extraction tube.

Digested with  HNO3, H2O2_or HCl depending on the complexity of the samples. Prior to the determination, Se(VI) was reduced to Se(IV) with 3_mL of 6.0_mol_L_1_HCl, while heating at 100_çC by 7_min. Finally, the samples were filtered, adjusted to 20% (v/v) HCl and diluted to 50_mL in a volumetric flask with ultrapure water.

Samples were lyophilized, powdered and digested HNO3 (BV-III grade reagent) and H2O2 (MOS grade reagent) (8 : 1 (v/v)). The transparent solution was volatilized to a volume of 0.5 mL at 90 1C, and then diluted with 2% HNO3 (containing 0.01% b-mercaptoethanol) up to 5 mL for Se analysis.

Methanol was used. Ultrasonic extraction (UAE) was performed in an ultrasonic extractor that allows variation of temperature. A sample of powdered garlic was macerated in a glass beaker with water at the optimal pH, and the suspensions were sonicated with the ultrasonic power.

Garlic samples: the SPME fiber was first derivatized by HS sampling the solid derivation agent in a 20 mL HS vial. Then headspace extraction of the thiol sample was carried out with the derivatized fiber under the following conditions: HS extraction time, 60 min; extraction temperature, 50 çC; agitation rate, 750 rpm. Before and after each run, the SPME fiber was conditioned for 3 min at 250 çC. No carry-over was noted after such conditioning. As part of the automated method protocol, standards were placed randomly in the run sequence and a fiber blank (to allow monitoring of the fiber integrity) was run as every eighth sample in the run sequence.

The derivatization reagent was loaded onto the NTD by extracting a 60 mL sample volume at a rate of 1 mL min_1_at 60 çC for 20 min from the headspace of 1 g of solid reagent. After loading of the derivatization reagent, a 20 mL mixture of the thiol standards was extracted at 0.2 mL min_1for 60 min at 60 çC. Under similar conditions as described for the SPME method.

Then headspace extraction of the thiol sample was carried out with the derivatized fiber under the following conditions: HS extraction time, 60 min; extraction temperature, 50 çC; agitation rate, 750 rpm. Before and after each run, the SPME fiber was conditioned for 3 min at 250 çC. No carry-over was noted after such conditioning. The derivatization reagent was loaded onto the NTD by extracting a 60 mL sample volume at a rate of 1 mL min_1_at 60 çC for 20 min from the headspace of 1 g of solid reagent. After loading of the derivatization reagent, a 20 mL mixture of the thiol standards was extracted at 0.2 mL min_1for 60 min at 60 çC. Under similar conditions as described for the SPME method.

method: ultra-performance liquid chromatography_photodiode array detector_mass spectrometry (UPLC_PDA_MS) Method
Sample_preparation: The powder samples were extracted with 2methanol acidified with 1% acetic acid. The extraction was performed twice and the supernatant was filtered through a Hydropilic PTFE 0.20 _m membrane and used for analysis.

For each independent analysis, at least 500_g of garlic, added with 100_mL Milli-Q water, were put in a commercial juice extractor (, obtaining a fluid vegetable extract (FVE) which was used in all analyses. In order to get the highest extraction efficiency of LMW-PPs, different partitioning solvents namely methanol (MeOH; 100%), water (H2O; 100%), ethyl acetate (EtAc; 100%), acetonitrile (MeCN; 100%) and MeCN:EtAc (50:50, v/v).

Garlic was freeze-dried, pulverized, extracted in a 250_mL glass vessel with 5_mL distilled water and 40_mL acetone, and oscillated for 30_min on a pulsator. Then, 3_g sodium chloride and 40_mL methylene dichloride were added into the mixture and oscillated for 30_min again. The oscillated mixture was then filtered through a glass fiber filter filled with anhydrous sodium sulphate, which was firstly rinsed with methylene dichloride before being filtered. The filtered solution was transferred to a round-bottomed flask and concentrated into a drop in a vacuum rotary evaporator, and then 10_mL petroleum ether was added into the flask and concentrated into a drop. In succession, 10_mL petroleum ether and certain anhydrous sodium sulphate were added into the flask and concentrated into a drop again. Afterward, the third 10_mL petroleum ether was added into the flask and the solution was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated to near dryness in a vacuum rotary evaporator and its volume was adjusted into 1_mL. The samples were sealed in vials and stored at _4çC before analysis.
The sample digestion procedure was as follows: 5_mL HNO3_and 1_mL H2O2_were added into Teflon reactor containing garlic. Then the residuals were dissolved by 10_mL dilute HNO3_(1%, v/v).

EOs were obtained from garlic cloves chopped, mixed in a blender and mixed with distilled water. EOs were collected in petroleum ether layer in the oil separator tube. When the extraction finished, petroleum ether layer was collected in a centrifuge tube and left at room temperature to evaporate petroleum ether.

Acetonitrile was added to the sample, next anhydrous NaCl (1 g) and anhydrous MgSO4 (4 g) were added into the mixture. After centrifugation the clarified supernatant was introduced into a 2.0-mL micro-centrifuge tube containing 10 mg MWCNTs and 150 mg MgSO4. Finally, the acetonitrile layer was filtered through a 0.22-mm filter membrane and 0.5 mL of the extract was placed into a GC vial (containing 10 m L 5 mg/L TPP) to carryout the chromatographic analysis.

Acetonitrile was added to the sample, next anhydrous NaCl (1 g) and anhydrous MgSO4 (4 g) were added into the mixture. After centrifugation the clarified supernatant was introduced into a 2.0-mL micro-centrifuge tube containing 10 mg MWCNTs and 150 mg MgSO4. Finally, the acetonitrile layer was filtered through a 0.22-mm filter membrane and 0.5 mL of the extract was placed into a GC vial (containing 10 m L 5 mg/L TPP) to carryout the chromatographic analysis.

method: on-line ionic liquid dispersive microextraction and electrothermal atomic absorption spectrometry
Sample_preparation: Ultrasound-assisted extraction of inorganic Se species was performed after freeze-dried garlic sample with 1_mol_L_1_H2SO4. The slurry was sonicated for 10_min, and the sulfuric extract separated by centrifugation at 3500_rpm (2054.3___g) for 10_min. The sulfuric extract was filtered. The solid residue was washed with 10_mL of water; this suspension was centrifuged for additional 10_min and the filtered supernatant was mixed with the previous extract. A volume of 1_mL of concentrated HCl was added to a 5_mL extract aliquot and heated in a hot plate at 100_çC for at least 20_min to reduce Se(VI) to Se(IV) and then total inorganic Se was determined. Another aliquot was acidified to a final HCl concentration of 0.5_mol_L_1_and submitted to the pre-concentration procedure to determine Se(IV).

method: High Performance Liquid ChromatographyAnalysis o
Sample_preparation: Carotenoids were extracted from A. sativum samples ethanol containing 0.1% ascorbic acid (w/v). Subsequently, 120 _L of potassium hydroxide (80% w/v) was added to saponify any potentially interfering oils. The samples were placed on ice and cold deionized water and  _-apo80 -carotenal (12.5 _g 3 mL 1 ), an internal standard, were added. Next, the carotenoids were extracted twice with hexane and centrifuged at 1200g each time to separate the layers. The extracts were freeze-dried under a stream of nitrogen gas and resuspended in 50:50 (v/v) dichloromethane/methanol.

Stock solutions (20_mg_ml_1) were prepared by dissolving the powder in PBS (0.1_M, pH 6.8) or culture medium, vortex mixing for 10_min and centrifuging at 3000g_for 20_min. Solutions were then filtered through 0.2__m porosity syringe filters, diluted as required in culture medium and used immediately. Metronidazole (Sigma) was dissolved in acidified buffer (final concentration 50_mM), slowly brought back to pH 6.8 with NaOH, filtered through a 0.2__m porosity syringe filter, diluted as required and used immediately.

Garlic sprout sample was cut into small pieces and 1.0_g of the crushed sample was weighed into a 15_mL septum-sealed amber vial and subjected to HS-SPME using the ZnO/graphene fiber for 30_min at room temperature. After that, the adsorbed volatiles were thermally desorbed by inserting the fiber into GC injector at 250_çC for 5_min.

The allicin was extracted from 10 g of garlic cloves using a utility electric vegetable crusher (TK-102, Tescom, Tokyo). After crushing, 10 ml of water was poured into the crusher, and the juice and debris of the garlic were collected into a centrifuge tube. The resulting supernatant was analyzed for antibacterial activity and allicin content

variation: A. sativum L. cv Yamuna safed
Sample_preparation: Healthy leaves were sampled and samples were immediately shock-frozen in liquid nitrogen and subsequently freeze-dried to prevent the decomposition of alliin. For HPTLC analysis, 1 g dry leaf powder was extracted at room temperature by using 10 ml methanol_water (80:20, v/v) plus 0.05% formic acid (pH 3) following method described previously by Arnault et al. (2003).

method: ICP-AES/inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry
Sample_preparation: fresh garlic was freeze-dried, and then crushed to fine garlic powder. Pure water extraction, 0.1 M HNO3 extraction, microwave digestion, and dry-weight tests were carried out with aliquots of 0.5 g of the fine garlic powder.

measurement: amount in mg/100 g of dry weight
method: HPLC profiles of free and soluble ester- and glycoside-bound phenolic acids
Sample_preparation: Defatted lyophilized garlic samples were extracted from a 50 mg aliquot with 5 mL of 1.2 M HCl in 50% methanol/water with heating at 90 çC for total polyphenols. The samples were cooled, diluted to 10 mL with methanol, and centrifuged for 5 min at 4000g with a benchtop centrifuge to remove solids.

Garlic clove homogenizing and added to 150 mL of 90% methanol solution containing 0.01 M HCl and then homogenized. The homogenate was decanted into a 250 mL flask. The homogenizing cup was washed with 90% methanol solution containing 0.01 M HCl, and the washing solution was combined with the homogenate to make exactly 250 mL. The mixture was centrifuged at 11000g for 5 min, and the supernatant was analyzed by HPLC.

hydroxylamine digestion

The dry garlic samples (0.2_g) were mixed with 10_mL of water and 20_mg of proteolytic enzyme in a stoppered glass tube. The treatment was carried out for 24_hours at 37 çC using magnetic stirring. Following the enzymatic treatment, the samples were centrifuged and passed through a 0.45__m pore size filter and then through a 12_kDa cut-off filter using a cooled (4 çC) centrifuge. The sample extracts were diluted appropriately with water prior to selenium analysis or selenium speciation analysis.

The dry garlic samples (0.2_g) were mixed with 10_mL of the hydroxylamine hydrochloride solution in a stoppered polyethylene vial. The samples were extracted using magnetic stirring for one_hour in a water bath at 37 çC. The supernatants were isolated by centrifugation and filtered by passage through a 12_kDa cut-off filter using a cooled (4 çC) centrifuge.

The fresh garlic cloves were peeled and the whole cloves (approximately 20_g) immediately covered with 200_mL of the same solution and homogenised using a titanium-bladed Omni-Mixer (Sorvall, Newtown, CT, USA). The samples were extracted using magnetic stirring for one_hour in a water bath at 37 çC. The supernatants were isolated by centrifugation and filtered by passage through a 12_kDa cut-off filter using a cooled (4 çC) centrifuge.

In a 50-mL flask, garlicpowder (1 g) was added to 30 mL of 90% methanol solution containing0.01 N HCl, and the mixture was shaken for 30 min using an SR-IIrecipro shaker (Taitec, Tokyo, Japan). Additional 90% methanolsolution containing 0.01 N HCl was added to the mixture to makeexactly 50 mL. The resulting mixture was centrifuged at 11000g for 5min using a benchtop KM-15200 microcentrifuge (Kubota, Tokyo,Japan). The obtained supernatant was analyzed by HPLC

A peeled garlic clove (4-10 g) in a 250-mL homogenizing cup was added to 150 mL of 90%methanol solution containing 0.01 N HCl and then homogenized atthe highest speed for 1 min using a 7012 laboratory blender (WaringProducts, Inc., Torrington, CT). The homogenate was decanted into a250-mL flask. The homogenizing cup was washed with a 90% methanolsolution containing 0.01 N HCl, and the washing solution was combinedwith the homogenate to make exactly 250 mL. The mixture wascentrifuged at 11000g for 5 min, and the supernatant was analyzed byHPLC.

variation: Spanish Roja; var. opioscorodon; hardneck, rocambole
Sample_preparation: Filtered garlic extract and internal standard (norvaline at a concentration of 200 µmol/L) were placed in a glass vial and slowly absorbed through a 40 µL resin-packed sorbent tip (15) by a 1.5 mL syringe. The resin was then rinsed with washing solution. Residual liquid was removed by pulling air through the sorbent tip. The sorbent particleswere collected reagent 4 was added to the glass vial and vortexed for 5 s. Reagent 5 was added and then vortexed for 5 s, and the reaction was left to proceed for another1 min. FID reagent 6 (100 µL) was added and vortexed for 5 s, and then the top organic layer was transferred into a GC vial containing aninsert for the FID analysis.

The resin was then rinsed with washing solution. Residual liquid was removed by pulling air through the sorbent tip. The sorbent particleswere collected reagent 4 was added to the glass vial and vortexed for 5 s. Reagent 5 was added and then vortexed for 5 s, and the reaction was left to proceed for another1 min. FID reagent 6 (100 µL) was added and vortexed for 5 s, and then the top organic layer was transferred into a GC vial containing aninsert for the FID analysis.

The resin was then rinsed with washing solution. Residual liquid was removed by pulling air through the sorbent tip. The sorbent particleswere collected reagent 4 was added to the glass vial and vortexed for 5 s. Reagent 5 was added and then vortexed for 5 s, and the reaction was left to proceed for another1 min. FID reagent 6 (100 µL) was added and vortexed for 5 s, and then the top organic layer was transferred into a GC vial containing aninsert for the FID analysis.

Sample_preparation: Filtered garlic extract and internal standard (norvaline at a concentration of 200 µmol/L) were placed in a glass vial and slowly absorbed through a 40 µL resin-packed sorbent tip (15) by a 1.5 mL syringe. The resin was then rinsed with washing solution. Residual liquid was removed by pulling air through the sorbent tip. The sorbent particleswere collected reagent 4 was added to the glass vial and vortexed for 5 s. Reagent 5 was added and then vortexed for 5 s, and the reaction was left to proceed for another1 min. FID reagent 6 (100 µL) was added and vortexed for 5 s, and then the top organic layer was transferred into a GC vial containing aninsert for the FID analysis.

The dry garlic slices (10 g) were milled into a powderand suspended in water (200 ml) for 30 min using a magneticstirrer. The solution and residue were then separatedusing centrifugation. The separated solution wassaturated with sodium chloride, and extracted 3 timeswith 200 ml each of dichloromethane. The combineddichloromethane extract was dehydrated with anhydroussodium sulfate and subsequently evaporated to dryness.The resulting yellow and strongly smelling residue wasdissolved in acetonitrile.

The garlic shoots frozen, powdered, and dissolved with 20 mL water, with sonication for 15 min, and continually shaken in dark at 150 rpm for 12 h at 298 K. After the supernatant solution was decanted and filtered through a 0.22 lm membrane to furnish a water-soluble extract of the garlic shoots. It was stored in a polyethylene bottle at 277 K before use.

The garlic shoots frozen, powdered, and dissolved with 20 mL water, with sonication for 15 min, and continually shaken in dark at 150 rpm for 12 h at 298 K. After the supernatant solution was decanted and filtered through a 0.22 lm membrane to furnish a water-soluble extract of the garlic shoots. It was stored in a polyethylene bottle at 277 K before use.

Raw Onions. After tap water (150 mL) and onions (100 g) were mixed, the onions were minced for 1 min using a homogenizer. The sample was then spiked with [2 H2]-1 [0.5-2 µg, dissolved in dichloromethane (0.5 mL), depending on the amounts expected] and stirred for 50 min in a closed vessel. After the addition of dichloromethane (200 mL), the sample was stirred for another 50 min. The mixture was centrifuged to break the emulsion formed, and, after the solvent had been decanted off, the extraction was repeated twice (total volume ) 100 mL). The organic layers were combined, dried over Na2SO4, and, after the solvent had been distilled off to _100 mL, the volatile compounds were separated from the nonvolatile material using the solvent-assisted flavor evaporation (SAFE) technique (10). The distillate was dried over sodium sulfate and concentrated to _1 mL on a Vigreux column (60 _ 1 cm) and to _300 µL using a microdistillation device (11). The same procedure was also applied to the other raw Allium varieties or vegetables, respectively.

About 50 g of garlic samples and 100 mL of distilled water were placed in a 250 mL round flask and 7 mL of dichloromethane were placed in a 10 mL round flask connected to the modified Likens_Nickerson micro SDE apparatus. Chilled water was circulated through the cold finger condenser. The extraction was continued for 8 h. After this reflux time the dichloromethane fractions of the solvent flask and the return loop were collected. The dichloromethane extracts were then dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate

Flavor components were collected from the garlic samples by using a SPTE apparatus (Fig. 1) designed in our laboratory. At first, a sample of 100 g was cut into pieces with a knife and sealed in a 250 mL round bottom flask. Volatile flavor components were collected for 2 h at ambient temperature by use of the SPTE device packed with ethylvinyl benzene divinyl benzene copolymer adsorbent (Porapak-Q, Supelco, 149_125 µm), a procedure identical with that in our previous reports [24, 26, 27, 28, 29]. Prior to use, Porapak-Q particles were pre-rinsed with organic solvent to remove impurities. The inlet of the Pasteur pipet was attached to the flask containing the garlic samples. An oil-free electric vacuum pump (Vacuubrand, Wertheim, Germany; diaphragm ME2 model, 2.4 m3 h_1) and a PTFE valve restrictor were connected with Tygon tubing to the outlet end of the trap via glass-manifold. Purified nitrogen gas (purity 99.99%) flow ca. 400 mL min_1 was passed into a flask and out through the adsorbent trap under reduced pressure. After a run the retained compounds were eluted with 2 mL dichloromethane. The eluate was then concentrated to final volume of approximately 200 µL on a water bath at 40 çC.

All SPME holders and coating fibers were obtained from Supelco (Bellefonte, PA, USA). For SPME sampling, five SPME devices including 50/30 µm divinylbenzene/carboxen/polydimethylsiloxane (DVB/CAR/PDMS), 100 µm polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS), 30 µm PDMS, 85 µm polyacrylate (PA), and 65 µm Carbowax/divinylbenzene (CW/DVB) were used. Prior to use SPME fibers were conditioned by heating them in the hot injection port of a gas chromatograph at 250_320 çC for 30_240 min in order to remove contaminants. Prior to analysis, a fiber blank was run to confirm the absence of contaminant peaks.

For SPME sampling, five SPME devices including 50/30 µm divinylbenzene/carboxen/polydimethylsiloxane (DVB/CAR/PDMS), 100 µm polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS), 30 µm PDMS, 85 µm polyacrylate (PA), and 65 µm Carbowax/divinylbenzene (CW/DVB) were used. Prior to use SPME fibers were conditioned by heating them in the hot injection port of a gas chromatograph at 250_320 çC for 30_240 min in order to remove contaminants. Prior to analysis, a fiber blank was run to confirm the absence of contaminant peaks.

After the conversion of organic sulfur to sulfate, total sulfur was determined (14) as follows: a 1-g sample of dried garlic powder was ashed at 450çC in the presence of 10 mL of 2.7 mol/L Mg(NO3)2. The ash was then boiled for 2 min in 10 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid (36 mol/100 mol), diluted in distilled water to dissolve the sulfate, filtered to remove insoluble material and the volume corrected to 100 mL. A 3-mL aliquot was analyzed for sulfate content using an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrophotometer (Jobin Yvon, Middlesex, UK), calibrated using a 574__mol/L K2SO4_standard stock solution.

First, 1 g of garlic dry powder was extracted at room temperature using 10 ml methanol_water (80:20, v/v)+0.05% formic acid (pH <3). An aliquot was diluted five times and filtrated (0.2 _m). Then, 10 _l were injected.
The solvent used was ethanol (purity 96% v/v)
The solvent used was acetone (purity 99.5%)

Garlic samples were immediately treated after light irradiation. The root was removed by cutting, then the irradiated side was separated from the non-irradiation side. Each part was weighed and homogenized with about 30 ml of methanol. The resulting homogenate was transferred to a 50 ml volumetric flask with methanol added to fill the flask. A part of this mixture was centrifuged at 15000 rpm for 5 min using a microcentrifuge, then the supernatant was used for the analytical sample solution.

The plants were cleaned, oven-dried at 40 çC, and ground, and 62.5% aqueous methanol containing 2 g/L TBHQ was added. To every 20 mL of aqueous methanol used was added 5 mL of 6M HCl. Extraction solution thus obtained consisted of 1.2M HCl in 50% aqueous methanol, v/v. These were carefully mixed and refluxed at 90 çC for 2 h. The extract was cooled, filtered using a Bu‘ chner filter, made to 50 mL with methanol, and filtered again with 0.45 µm Whatman membrane filter before injection into the HPLC.

preparation: _raw garlic cloves were homogenized with an equivalent volume of water in a Waring blender. The homogenate was filtered through gauze and the filtrate was obtained (RGJ)._
Sample_preparation: RGJ or HGJ (2 mL) was applied into an ion-exchange column containing 4 mL of NH41 form resin. After being washed with 40 mL of water, the sample solution was eluted by 0.2 mol/L aqueous ammonium (20 mL). The effluent was appropriately diluted with 0.2 mol/L aqueous ammonium, if necessary. HPLC analysis was performed

preparation: S-Butylcysteine sulfoxide was used as an internal standard
Sample_preparation: About 10 g of carefully peeled garlic cloves were steeped overnight into cold methanol to allow penetration of methanol into the cellular tissue. The plant material was then cut in small pieces and after addition of_S-butylcysteine sulfoxide (BCSO, 20 mg/ml) homogenized by using a high speed tissue homogenizer. The homogenate was then extracted with 2_100 ml of boiling methanol. The combined methanolic extracts were reduced to approximately 15 ml at 40çC and adjusted to 25 ml by addition of 3% HCl. A precipitate usually appeared on the acidification. The extract was filtered and a volume of 3 ml was passed through a column (1_5 cm) of a cation-exchange resin (Dowex 50 WX 4, H+_form, 50_100 mesh), which was pretreated with 10 ml of 3% HCl. The column was then treated with 10 ml of 3% HCl and 20 ml of deionized water to remove interfering non-cationic substances present in the extract. These fractions were discarded. The amino acids were eluted from the column with 50 ml of 1_M_ammonium hydroxide. The eluate was evaporated to dryness by using a rotary flash evaporator (at 40_50çC). The residue obtained (usually white or yellowish) was used for both GC and HPLC analyses.

The homogenate was then extracted with 2_100 ml of boiling methanol. The combined methanolic extracts were reduced to approximately 15 ml at 40çC and adjusted to 25 ml by addition of 3% HCl. A precipitate usually appeared on the acidification. The extract was filtered and a volume of 3 ml was passed through a column (1_5 cm) of a cation-exchange resin (Dowex 50 WX 4, H+_form, 50_100 mesh), which was pretreated with 10 ml of 3% HCl. The column was then treated with 10 ml of 3% HCl and 20 ml of deionized water to remove interfering non-cationic substances present in the extract. These fractions were discarded. The amino acids were eluted from the column with 50 ml of 1_M_ammonium hydroxide. The eluate was evaporated to dryness by using a rotary flash evaporator (at 40_50çC). The residue obtained (usually white or yellowish) was used for both GC and HPLC analyses.

location: Freeze-dried. Each freeze-dried sample (1 g) was extracted with two portions of 40-mL double deionized water heated to reflux for 1 h. The cooled sample was centrifuged for 15 min at 10 000 rpm after each water extraction; the supernatants were combined and made up to 100 mL with water. The aqueous extract was then filtered with a Millipore HA 0.45-µm membrane
Sample_preparation: The frozen sample extracts were allowed to warm to room temperature. Samples were prepared by taking 50 µL of extract and mixing this with 50 µL of aqueous 0.01 M potassium chloride solution. The standard addition samples had GF4 (7.9 _ 10-4 M in 50 µL aqueous 0.01 M potassium chloride) added to 50-µL sample extracts.

preparation: Crude garlic extract was prepared by mechanically crushing garlic cloves and resuspending it (2 g/10 ml)in 50 mM Na_phosphate, pH 6.5, containing 1 mM EDTA for 10 min. The content of allicin was determined in the filtrate
Sample_preparation: the product interaction of allicin with NTB (Amax 5 336 nm) (c). NTB (10 mmol) was reacted with allicin (8 mmol) in buffer A (final volume, 1.0 ml) at room temperature. Five minutes later an aliquot was diluted 1:100 with 0.1% formic acid in 60% methanol in water. Fifty microliters was separated by HPLC

Amino acid analysis was carried out on a protein hydrolysate obtained by heating a sample in 6 N HCl for 24 h at 110çC in a sealed tube followed by separation using a Beckmann Model 6300 amino acid analyzer (17). Tryptophan content was estimated in an unhydrolyzed sample by the procedure of Edelhoch.

In a 25 mL flask, garlic powder (0.5 g) was added to 15 mL of a 90% methanol solution containing 0.01 M HCl, and the mixture was shaken for 30 min at 900 rpm using a multipoint magnetic stirrer  SBS, Barcelona, Spain). An additional methanolic solution was added to the mixture to make exactly 25 mL.

preparation: A portion of blanched garlic cloves was packed into ñB250îglass bottles (150 g of garlic cloves plus 110 mL of cover liquidcapacity) using a brine acidified with lactic acid (packing solution 1,PS1) as cover liquid. Concentrations (in %) of lactic acid and NaCl inthis brine were calculated to give equilibrium values of 1.5% acidity (aslactic acid) and 3.0% NaCl.

An additional methanolic solution was added to the mixture to make exactly 25 mL.

preparation: A portion of blanched garlic cloves was packed into ñB250îglass bottles (150 g of garlic cloves plus 110 mL of cover liquidcapacity) using a brine acidified with lactic acid (packing solution 1,PS1) as cover liquid. Concentrations (in %) of lactic acid and NaCl inthis brine were calculated to give equilibrium values of 1.5% acidity (aslactic acid) and 3.0% NaCl.
